awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Impacts of Ion-Neutral Coupling on Ion Upflow and Outflow in the Polar Cusp
awd_abstract_narration:
Numerical modeling is one of the popular tools of modern space and atmospheric sciences. Computer simulations and numerical experiments allow the investigation various processes in the Earth environment and predict outcomes of these processes. Comparison with actual observational data allows the tuning of numerical models and improving this scientific tool. Many noted institutions are working on creating and constantly improving these models allowing scientists to utilize them for their research. Thus, the objective of the research will allow better understanding of the solar wind - magnetosphere interaction and improving global-scale coupled geospace models.
 
This recommended collaborative effort is to investigate the dynamics and features of the interaction between ions and neutral atoms of the ionosphere and thermosphere during geomagnetic storms. The research focuses on how this interaction affects the upflow and outflow of ions. This investigation will consist of a series of numerical experiments applying global-scale geospace numerical models. Coupled Magnetosphere Ionosphere Thermosphere model (CMIT) will be used in combination with Ionosphere / Polar Wind Model (IPWM) to analyze how thermospheric changes can affect the ion upflow and outflow simulated in the IPWM. CMIT model is a combination of the Lyon-Fedder-Mobarry (LFM) Magnetospheric MHD model, the Magnetosphere Ionosphere Exchange (MIX) model of high-latitude electrodynamics, and the Thermosphere Ionosphere Electrodynamics General Circulation Model (TIEGCM). The research also concentrates on studying how the solar wind features and dynamics affect the ion-neutral interaction in the cusp and cleft and on finding specific distinctive signatures of this coupling, which could be recognized by ground-based instruments, for example, incoherent scatter radars at high latitudes.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the influence of upper atmospheric dynamics on the near-Earth space environment. Specifically, we studied how changes in the state of the thermosphere, the uppermost layer of the atmosphere, control the rate at which ions escape gravity to populate and structure geospace. The magnetosphere, a tenuous magnetic cavity surrounding the Earth and beyond which the solar wind is mostly deflected, is populated by two distinct sources of ions: 1) the solar wind; and 2) ion outflows from the ionosphere, the ionized portion of Earth’s upper atmosphere. The ionosphere overlaps in altitude with the thermosphere and is created primarily by extreme ultraviolet (EUV)  solar radiation that ionizes atoms and molecules of the thermosphere with a pronounced modulation due to the 22-year solar cycle. We explored how ionospheric outflows influence the interaction between the thermosphere, ionosphere, and magnetosphere (TIM), with emphasis on how frictional coupling between the fluids of the thermosphere and ionosphere affect this interaction.

We investigated the coupled TIM dynamics using numerical models, which required merging three existing models: 1) the Thermosphere Ionosphere Electrodynamics General Circulation Model (TIEGCM); 2) the Ionosphere Polar Wind Model (IPWM) describing ionospheric outflows; and 3) the multi-fluid Lyon Fedder Mobarry model (MFLFM) describing the global magnetohydrodynamics of the magnetosphere. Previous studies investigated the effects of ionospheric outflows on the magnetosphere using dynamically coupled magnetosphere and polar wind models with the underlying thermospheric state described by a static empirical model. A major innovation of this project involved replacing the empirical model with TIEGCM’s dynamically evolving thermosphere and coupling it to the MFLFM and IPWM. Model inputs and parameters were constrained by observations.

The coupled models and (by inference) the actual TIM system include numerous pathways for interaction and feedback, so we designed a set of controlled numerical experiments (simulations) to isolate the thermosphere’s influence on the coupled system. We performed simulations that were identical in every way except for the state of the thermosphere (TIEGCM), which was allowed to influence the magnetospheric state (MFLFM) only via ionospheric outflows (IPWM). All other forcings of the coupled system were the same between the simulations, including solar wind forcing of the magnetosphere and the thermosphere’s electrodynamic influence on the magnetosphere arising from resistive drag  of the ionosphere, which had already been studied extensively. Comparing and contrasting these simulations allowed us to quantify effects due solely to the changes in the thermosphere and its regulation of ionospheric outflows and to determine cause and effect manifest in ground- and space-based observations.

Our experiments demonstrated that when the thermosphere is hotter and more expanded, as occurs during solar maximum, the rate of ion outflow into the magnetosphere is increased. The extra mass added the magnetosphere has consequences for a wide range of other magnetospheric processes, including the coupling between the magnetosphere and solar wind and the structure of the magnetotail. Overall, we found changes in the thermosphere have direct consequences for the entire geospace environment.

In addition to this study, we performed several related experiments using the coupled models including investigations of: the ways different kinds of particle precipitation from the magnetosphere into the ionosphere and thermosphere affect ion outflow; the generation of traveling atmospheric disturbances by magnetosphere-ionosphere interactions; and how heating by small-scale, low-frequency magnetohydrodynamic waves changes the thermospheric density. The coupled models developed during this project are useful for a wide variety of future investigations of the complex TIM interactions. Ultimately, understanding these interactions is paramount for predicting space weather and the ways in which the dynamics of the space environment impact technological systems and human activities.

In addition to advancing knowledge of space weather, new results were disseminated to the broader scientific community in three technical manuscripts (in review for publication), 13 presentations at national and international scientific conferences and one MS thesis. The project contributed to workforce development by: 1) supporting, training, and mentoring a postdoctoral scientist; 2) training and mentoring a Dartmouth College MS student; and 3) providing a summer research experience for a Coe College student under the auspices of the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Program in Solar and Space Physics of the Boulder Solar Alliance. All three trainees acquired new skills in the science and numerical simulation of the global thermosphere-ionosphere-magnetosphere and its applications to space weather phenomena. The postdoc is continuing state-of-art geospace research and model development at NCAR’s High Altitude Observatory (HAO). The former MS student has entered the PhD program in Aerospace Engineering at the University of Colorado and is pursuing research and spacecraft sensor development for space weather applications. The former undergraduate student decided to pursue graduate study in space physics as a consequence of her REU training and is now a PhD student in physics at the University of New Hampshire.
